titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Angus MacLise Sound Recordings
titlestmt.author: by Molly Wheeler

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday April 11, 2019 at 03:01

did.unittitle: Angus MacLise sound recordings

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Angus MacLise Sound Recordings document selected musical work of Angus MacLise. The sound recordings are 5 and 7.5 inch reel-to-reel audio tapes that consist of experimental music composed and performed by MacLise in solo performances and in collaboration with other musicians and artists. The recordings span the years 1965 to 1978.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 1-2 (audiovisual material): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Angus MacLise Sound Recordings is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Angus MacLise Sound Recordings. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

bioghist.head: Angus MacLise
bioghist.p: Angus MacLise was born on March 4, 1938 in Bridgeport, CT. He studied various genres of percussion and dance, performing with several ensembles before entering the downtown New York City music scene. In the early 1960s, he wrote and published poetry through Dead Language Press, which he co-founded with filmmaker Piero Heliczer. The press also published MacLise's combination calendar/poem, Year , which assigned names to each day of the year. MacLise was a member of La Monte Young's Theater of Eternal Music with John Cale, Tony Conrad, Marian Zazeela, and Terry Riley. In 1965, MacLise lived with Cale and along with him, Lou Reed and Sterling Morrison, formed the musical group The Velvet Underground. MacLise performed with them regularly throughout the year but quit in late 1965 and was replaced by Maureen Tucker. He played with them again for a few performances in 1966 when Reed was briefly hospitalized.

McLise was a student of the occultist and mystic Aleister Crowley and under the influence of his teachings, began to blend Tibetan mysticism with his music to create sound through various drone techniques. From 1965 through the 1970s, MacLise was active in the New York City underground music scene, integrating trance, improvisation, spoken word, poetry, and electronics into his performances. He collaborated with several notable artists on multimedia projects, such as Gerard Malanga, Yoko Ono, Jonas Mekas, and Jerry Jofen. In the late 1960s, MacLise married illustrator Hetty McGee, and together they played in the musical group, Universal Mutant Repertory Company. The group did a series of performances in New York's St. Mark's Church in 1970, titled "Epiphanies." In the early 1970s, he devoted more of his time to poetry and calligraphy, and also started a literary magazine, Ting-Pa .

Later in his life, MacLise traveled to study the ethnic percussion traditions in Morocco, Turkey, Syria, Iraq, Iran, Afghanistan, Pakistan, and India with various local teachers and groups. He settled in Nepal, where he died of hypoglycemia in Kathmandu on June 21, 1979.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Angus MacLise Sound Recordings document the musical work of Angus MacLise. The reel-to-reel audio tapes consist of experimental music performed by MacLise in solo performances and in collaboration with other musicians and artists. The sound recordings span the years 1965 to 1978.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged according to a numbering system assigned by MacLise.

did.unittitle: Sound Recordings

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Sound recordings are arranged according to a numbering system assigned by MacLise, "GM/AM 001-025." "GM" stands for Gerard Malanga, who assisted Hetty MacLise in rehousing the tapes before their transfer to the Beinecke Library. "AM" stands for Angus MacLise.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sound recordings consist of 28 reel-to-reel audio tapes. Most tapes have been rehoused into new reel boxes by Hetty MacLise and Malanga. Original boxes are filed next to the rehoused tapes since the original boxes contain MacLise's notes. Titles have been transcribed from original boxes. Tapes 1-9, and 24 are 7.5 inch reels. Tapes 10-23 and 25 are 5 inch reels.

There are three numbered tapes at the end of the series that are in original boxes. These tapes include GM/AM numbers that do not correspond to rehoused tapes. All are 7.5 inch reels. It is not clear as to why they were assigned duplicate numbers but were not rehoused. It is possible that they were not reviewed by Hetty MacLise and Malanga.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Boxes 1 and 2 (audiovisual material): Restricted fragile. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

did.unittitle: GM/AM-001. "Untitled. 7.5 ips, 2-track stereo."
did.materialspec: The first hour and 22 minutes is recorded at a very low level at times. The audio speeds up at times in the first four minutes. Stops and starts can also be heard. Static is heard on the tape. The program is distorted at times.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Audiovisual material. Restricted fragile. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

did.unittitle: GM/AM-002. "Recorded on Tandberg tape recorder. Epiphany at St. Mark's Church in the Bowery. 1970 January 6. 7.5 ips."
did.materialspec: The program begins and ends abruptly. The audio cuts in and out throughout the first 47 and a half minutes. The program is distorted at times. The program is recorded at a very high level. Audio in the right channel cuts out from around 1:12:26-1:18:59.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Audiovisual material. Restricted fragile. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

did.unittitle: GM/AM-003. "Musicians: Angus MacLise, Bill Breeze, Mark Slivka. Note: one track appears to come through from a second track. 3.75 ips half track one side. Other side 7.5 ips half track David Lewiston's Central Park tapes-1970."
did.materialspec: The program ends abruptly. The program is distorted at times.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Audiovisual material. Restricted fragile. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

did.unittitle: GM/AM-004. "Side 1: Expanded Media. Track A-Tibetan (Sikhim) chant and gong, 2/3 of tape. Track B- Electronic RTF experimental, last few minutes Tibetan again. 7.5 ips."
did.materialspec: Static can be heard on the tape. The program is distorted at times. Buzz can be heard on the tape from 23:45-47:07. A slight warble on the tape can be heard at about 1:17:00.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Audiovisual material. Restricted fragile. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

did.unittitle: GM/AM-005. "Quasar, St. Mark's in the Bowery. Note: Angus and Don's collaboration for Don's St. Mark's show. Performers: J. Taylor-organ, Frank-drums (Rabuffo's husband), Barney Rosteing-sax, Jimmy Lovelace-trumpet. 7.5 ips."
did.materialspec: Speed flucutations can be heard at about five seconds into the program.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Audiovisual material. Restricted fragile. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

did.unittitle: GM/AM-006. "Fantuzzi- India departure and MacLise Energy Center party. 7.5 ips mono full track. 32 minutes recording time."
did.materialspec: The program is distorted at times. It is recorded at a very high level. The program begins and ends abruptly.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Audiovisual material. Restricted fragile. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

did.materialspec: A high amount of hiss can be heard on the tape. The program is distorted at times. Static can be heard. The program ends abruptly.

did.unittitle: GM/AM-017. "Side 1: Epiphany-St. Mark's Church. Rehearsal. 7.5 ips. Side 2: 3.75 ips. Approximately 1 hour, 37 minutes."

GM/AM-019 a & b. "a) Birth and Death of the Planet Earth. Marymount show, live. Rehearsal, track 1. b) Drums and live show, track 2. 3.75 ips. Approximately 63 minutes."

GM/AM-024. "Track 1, Side 1: Forest and Aztec Chant. Track 2, Side 2: Drums and insect voices backwards. 7.5 ips with a 3.75 ips, 5 minute changeover. Note: Track 1, Side 2 and Track 2, Side 1 could not be located on tape. Approximately 30 minutes."

GM/AM-005. "Goeralegan and Dedication Ceremony (christening) of Mount Shango. Drums, flute declamation. Opens with Mick Jagger."
GM/AM-007. "Epiphany stereo 7.5, recording on side 1 only, Hetty chant and organ."
GM/AM-010. "Party, master track 1, 2, 3. Mostly blank."
